tourName: North East India tour, Assam & Meghalaya
generalInfo:
Discover the enchanting North-East India and the charm of Assam & Meghalaya's hidden treasures!

The Tour takes you off the beaten track, to the more remote areas of North East India and includes plenty of time in National Parks, natural areas, small villages, cultural and heritage stays, a 3-night stay on a houseboat and activities on the river - offering small group experiences instead of mass-market tourism, cultural immersion instead of on-board entertainment.

Itinerary:
Dibrugarh | Jorhat | Kaziranga | Nameri | Guwahati | Cherrapunjee | Shillong

Price Includes:
13 nights of accommodation
13 breakfast, 13 dinner and 10 lunches
AC SUV for the entire tour
Accompanied English speaking guide for the entire tour
Local ferry transfer to Majuli Island with local lunch
Jungle safari and all activities mentioned in the plan
All monument entrances as applicable

Best months for travel: from November to March

dayInfo.description: Arrival at Dibrugarh Airport: We receive you at Mohanbari Airport in Dibrugarh. After customary greetings, we take you to the hotel. Planters Bungalow check-in: We will check in at a lovely tea planter's bungalow, popularly known as Chang bungalow by lunchtime. After lunch, we have an opportunity to walk in the tea garden and know about Assam's famous flavoured CTCT tea. In the evening, a special cultural dance performance can be arranged over a bonfire on request.

Full day Dibrugarh: Today we have a long day to explore the surroundings of Dibrugarh. Namphake ethnic village (1.5hr drive): Meet the villages and interact with them to know more about their culture. Visit the most popular Namphake Buddhist Monastery which practices Theravada Buddhism. Digboi Excursion (40 km in 1hr): From Nampakhe, we drive to Digboi - the oldest oil refinery in the world. Visit the oil fields and the Assam Oil Museum. OR Dibru Saikhowa Excursion/Boat ride (45 km in 1.2hr): boat ride on the Brahmaputra, lunch on the boat, watch out for Gangetic dolphins and migratory birds, witness a fascinating sunset ((Boat ride is subject to river conditions)

Dibrugar to Jorhat via Sivasagar (by road - 140 KM. in 4 Hrs): Today we drive to Jorhat in central Assam - a tea country in the vast valley of the Brahmaputra River. *On our way, we visit Sivasagar, known for its Ahom Dynasty Palaces, Temples and old Monuments. *Tai Museum in Sivasagar: see invaluable artefacts of Ahom Kingdom. *Rang Ghar: this cultural playground of Ahom Monarchs remains the largest theatre in Asia. *Burra Shaib’s bungalow or the Thengal Manor:- a heritage bungalow originally used as a Visiting Agent’s bungalow by George Williamson; 125 years old and the total floor area is about 10,000 sq.ft. Soak in the colonial comfort of the bungalow and enjoy the serenity of the lush tea estate or the 18-hole, Par 71 Golf Course in the midst of a tea garden.

Full day at Majuli Island: We will drive to Nimatighat where the chartered or public ferry will take us to this magical land (1.15hr each way). On reaching the other side we will take another vehicle and enter inside the village. We will explore the village by foot and car and visit the Satras - the religious and cultural institution which played the pivotal role in uniting the people of assam during 15th Century. We will also see and learn about the different cultural activities including mask making, boat making, traditional fishing, pottery, weaving and bamboo craft. After a lunch organised in a local family house, we will return to the Ferry Dock and transfer to Jorhat.

Jorhat to Kaziranga- 2hrs: This morning, you can go for a visit to the famous Hoollongapar Gibbon Sanctuary 24kms from Jorhat. This is the only sanctuary for the apes in India known as Hoolock Gibbon. This evergreen sanctuary is also home for 7 primates including rare Slow Loris, stump tailed macaque, capped langur, assamese macaque etc. there is no forest safari but you can walk on the natures trail with a forest guide to find some of the primates in their natural habitat. Leave for Kaziranga around mid-morning. Reach towards early in the afternoon. Check into the resort. Kaziranga is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, home to some of the most fascinating wildlife in Asia. Especially its Rhino population - which is at 1600 - is the single largest in the world! Everything about Kaziranga is large. From 5 meter tall elephant-grass to Greater Adjutants, Bengal Floricans, Pallas's Fish Eagle, Black-necked Storks, Greater One-horned Rhinoceros and Asian Elephants, size dominates the vast grasslands. Kaziranga National Park in Assam has to be the most beautiful and attractive place you can choose to visit in north-eastern India.

Kaziranga Elephant safari in West or Central Range: You will have the option of visiting the park in an open hood jeep. The jeep safaris are ideally for 2hrs and you can have several 2hrs safaris during your stay in this park. You can enjoy the beauty of the Greater One Horned Rhinoceros with its majestic body and its charismatic horn, see herds of elephants and some most magnificent tuskers (if you are lucky!). You are sure to come across herds of Wild Buffalo with their magnificent horns. These are some of the last populations in the wild. You would also come across herds of Hog Deer, Sambar and Swamp Deer. Its a paradise for bird-watchers (please do not forget to bring your own binoculars). You could also come across wild boar, Hog Badgers, Porcupine. Red Jungle Fowl, Kaleej Pheasnt and Swamp Francolin could also be spotted, if you have sharp eyes and strong hearing. If you look towards the sky, you may be able to spot Pallas Fishing Eagle, Hornbills and Cranes in flight. And if you are lucky enough, you might as well come across a tiger or two. OR you can spend the day visiting a Mising Tribe village. Explore the village with your guide and learn their culture. A traditional Mising lunch can also be arranged in the village. You may also opt for a local boat ride in a small river and try to see the rare Gangetic Dolphin. Evening at leisure at your jungle lodge.

Kaziranga - Balipara (Tezpur) 80km in 2hrs: Drive to Balipara near Nameri National Park - a biodiversity hotspot, the National Park & Tiger Reserves of Northeast India. We will check-in at Wild Mahseer, set in the midst a lush Tea Estate in the central part of Assam. There is something of interest for everyone: the nature lover, the gourmet, the traditional farming fanatic, the relaxer, the meditator, the sportsman, the culture junkie, the wildlife enthusiast, the ornithologist and the adventurer. We will also visit an ethnic village and see the traditional lives of the local people. The Mising, the second largest ethnic group in Assam, originally a hill tribe from Tibet and Mongolia, settled on the plains of Assam around the 8th century. They have their language which can be traced to some Tibetan/Mongolic languages and which follows the Roman script. Enroute, we will visit the Tezpur town. Located on the ancient site of Sonitpur (meaning the City of Blood) so named, as legend has it, because of a battle fought there between Lord Krishna and Lord Shiva, it is steeped in mythology and folklore and renowned for its magnificent archaeological ruins and scenic beauty. Return to Wild Mahseer in the late afternoon and soak in the comfort of the bungalow.

Full-day Excursion to Nameri National Park with Optional Rafting: River Rafting on the Jia Bhoroli near Wild Mahseer is one of the most relaxing and tranquil experiences in the world and should not be missed. After breakfast at Wild Mahseer we drive past blooming mustard fields (in season) where, on a clear day, the snow-capped peaks of the Himalayas are in full view. Inflatable rafts and paddles await and with 2 rafting guides looking after each boat, an unforgettable voyage down the crystal clear waters of this beautiful Brahmaputra tributary begins. Guests can take up a paddle as they bob over the gentle rapids or simply soak up the peaceful panorama while being entertained by the antics of ruddy shelducks, soaring Pallas's fish eagles, graceful Brahmani kites and rows of black cormorants spreading out their wings to dry having just dived for a meal. After a couple of hours drifting down the river, guides pull the rafts onto the bank near the Nameri Forest Camp. We will have lunch in Nameri and return to Wild Mahseer in the afternoon.

Nameri National Park to Guwahati (220 kms in 5hrs): Today after breakfast we drive to Guwahati. Guwahati, on the bank of Brahmaputra River and at the foot of Shillong Plateau is an ancient town since the pre historical era and used to be an important seat of tantra and Vajrayana Buddhism. Guwahati has been a part of the state from the time immemorial and traces of the city are often found in Puranas or ancient epics. Mahabharata talks about Guwahati as the capital of Bhagadatta and Kamakhya. And it was referred to as "Pragjyotishpura", which means city of eastern light. Guwahati now, has also been mentioned as Durjaya in many places that indicates an invincible power ruling Kamrup during the time. Interesting ruins evoke a glorious past and many ancient temples scattered all over the city have brought it a title and it is also famous as the "The City of Temples." We check in to a nice hotel in the city and then you will have option of taking a relax personal time at the hotel or you can go for a Sunset Cruise to enjoy your evening with a relaxing and unforgettable sunset over the mighty Brahmaputra River. See the sun go down over the stunning landscape and then watch the stars appear in the night sky. The cruise will sail from Guwahati to North Guwahati and back for about an hour, so all you need to do is sit back, relax, and admire the view.

Guwahati- Cherrapunjee (5-6 hrs drive): Today we drive to Cherrapunjee. With a unique climate gifted to the area, its untouched beauty and an environment similar to the freshest dew drops, Cherrapunjee is sure to refresh you inside out. The waterfalls in the area only compliment the climate and the flattering pleasant air around. These include the Dain Thelen falls, Noh Sngithiang falls, Noh Kalikai falls and more. This rainy misty place is also famous for astounding tourists with the lavish spread of the Bangladesh plains from it's cliffs. This lovely town is also famous for its limestone caves, orange, honey, a headquarter of the Syiem of Sohra and a Centre of the Khasi Culture and literature. Reach Cherrapunjee resort in the afternoon. Check-in and rest. Night stay in Cherrapunjee.

Double Decker Living Roots bridge walk- 10 kms drive and 5-6 kms trek one way- 6-7 hrs round trip: The lower reaches of the southern slopes of Khasi and Jaintia hills in Meghalaya are humid and warm and are streaked by many swift flowing rivers and mountain streams. This is one of the most beautiful treks. The high point of this trek is the Double Decker Root Bridge and the natural swimming pools in the river bed. This trek is open through-out the year and is being used by the villagers daily. The rivers, streams and waterfalls in full flow during the monsoon months add magnificence to the root bridges spanning these rivers and streams. Before reaching the Double Decker Root Bridge you come across another Living Root Bridge and Steel Rope bridges. The valley scenery is very impressive. Beyond the Double Decker Root Bridge, you walk on level ground another 2 km (say 20 minutes) to reach Mawsaw Steel Rope Bridge. From here you access natural swimming pools. The larger pool is deep and we recommend only good swimmers to attempt it. The smaller pool can be used by others. After a refreshing swim, it is time for lunch. Leave the pool side by 2:30 p.m. to reach the top before it is dark.

Drive back to Shillong: Shillong is the Pop-music capital of India. Shillong is the capital Meghalaya (meaning 'the abode of the clouds'), located in undulating pine covered hills. The city centre is 1496m above sea level and currently has a population of around 270,000. Home to several waterfalls, it is also known as the Scotland of the East. The state is famous for heavy rainfalls, numerous cave, tallest waterfalls, beautiful landscapes and amazing people and culture. We will have a short tour in Shillong visiting local market and enroute we will stop for a photo break at Elephant Falls and continue driving to our overnight stay near Umium Lake. Tonight, we will stay at Ri Kynjai on the Umiam Lake or Barapani, the biggest artificial lake in the State, surrounded by sylvan hills and wrapped in the beauty of an assortment of green Khasi-pines and the azure blue skies. You have the full evening to relax in this splendid atmosphere.

Day excursion to Mawlynnong Village (80kms each way from Shillong): Today we have a full day-long excursion to Mawlynnong Village - known as the cleanest village in India. This picturesque village offers many interesting sights such as the 1000 years old living root bridge and another strange natural phenomenon of a boulder balancing on another rock. Mawlynnong nestled in the pristine hill state of Meghalaya along the Indo-Bangla border is known for its cleanliness. Mawlynnong's fame is now drawing an endless stream of guests from across the country and abroad. Roam around the village and walk along the natures trail to discover the wonders around you. We will have lunch in a local house and will return to Cherrapunjee in the evening. On your way, you can see the vast Sohra Plateau and a stunning bird's eye view of the villages in Bangladesh. The low flying fluffy monsoon clouds are swept over the hills and channelled through the deep valleys creating beautiful sceneries that will thrill any nature photographer. The monsoon clouds embracing the hills and uncovering the beauty of the freshly washed rainforests and the numerous throbbing silvery-white waterfalls will give you many enchanting opportunities to capture the unrivalled beauty of nature with your camera honed by your picture composing skills.
Shillong to Guwahati Airport – 90kms in 3hrs. Today we leave Shillong after breakfast and in time take you to Guwahati airport ot connect with Delhi or Kolkata. Tour ends
